Claims.expr: Find all f: R -> R such that f(x+y) + f(x)f(y) = f(xy) + 2xy + 1 for all x,y in R
f(x+y) + f(x)f(y) = f(xy) + 2xy + 1 for all x,y in R
If f(0) = 1, then f(x) = 1 for all x in R
The constant function f(x) = 1 does not satisfy the equation
Assume f is linear: f(x) = a x - 1
Substituting the linear form yields a^2 x y = (a + 2) x y
Assume f is quadratic: f(x) = c x^2 + d x - 1
Substituting quadratic form yields c^2 = c, c d = 0, 2c + d^2 = d + 2
For c = 1, d = 0, and equation holds
The functions are f(x) = 2x - 1, f(x) = -x - 1, f(x) = x^2 - 1
find all (x, y) in Z^2 such that x^3 - y^3 = 2 x y + 8
find all (x, y) in Z^2 such that x^(f(0) + 4) - y^3 = 2 x y + 8
all integers a_0 > 1 s.t. exists A with |{n >= 0 : a_n = A}| = infinity
a_{n+1} = sqrt(a_n) if sqrt(a_n) integer else a_n + 3
k^2 mod 3 in {0,1} for k in Z
if a_n equiv 2 mod 3 then sqrt(a_n) not integer
if a_0 equiv 2 mod 3 then forall n, a_n equiv 2 mod 3 and a_n = a_0 + 3n
if a_0 equiv 2 mod 3 then no such A
if k^2 equiv 0 mod 3 then k equiv 0 mod 3
if a_0 equiv 0 mod 3 then forall n a_n equiv 0 mod 3
if 3 | a_0 then sequence eventually enters {3,6,9} cycle
if 3 | a_0 then exists A=3 with infinitely many a_n = 3
no a >1 maps to 1 under the operation
if a_0 equiv 1 mod 3 then sequence never reaches 1
any sequence has finitely many sqrt steps
after last sqrt, sequence strictly increases by 3 forever, all distinct
if a_0 not equiv 0 mod 3 then every A appears finitely often
such a_0 are exactly those with 3 | a_0
all integers a_0 > (x + 1) s.t. exists A with |{n >= 0 : a_n = A}| = infinity
